dc:description:
The *THPO* gene encodes the ligand for *MPL*, thrombopoietin, a hematopoietic growth factor that regulates the development of megakaryocytes and platelets as well as the self-renewal of hematopoietic stem cells.

LUMPING AND SPLITTING CONSIDERATIONS:

Thrombocythemia 1; OMIM: 187950; MONDO:0008554 Thrombocytopenia, congenital amegakaryocytic; OMIM: 604498; MONDO: 0011469

Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in molecular mechanisms (loss of function vs gain of function), inheritance pattern (autosomal dominant vs autosomal recessive) and phenotypic variability (thrombocythemia vs thrombocytopenia) between these two phenotypes thus the disorders have been split. 

*THPO* was first reported in relation to congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner in 2013 (Dasouki et al., PMID: 24085763) in a Micronesian family.
 
Nonsense, missense and frameshift variants have been reported in humans thus far. The disease mechanism is loss of function. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes genetic evidence (case-level data) and experimental evidence (biochemical functions, protein interaction and animal model).

Summary of Case Level Data: 4.4 points: Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 5 probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 29191945, 24085763, 28559357). Five additional individuals from two publications (PMIDs: 28466964, 32150607) have been noted to have monoallelic loss of function variants. These individuals have been added to this gene-disease record, but not scored. The H/T GCEP is aware that there is published (5 cases) and unpublished (at least one individual with heterozygous nonsense variant, along with GFI1b C168F variant) evidence to suggest that there may be a semi-dominant mode of inheritance for the thrombocytopneia phenotype caused by *THPO* variants as heterozygous carrier relatives of probands with homozygous alterations also display reduced platelet counts (PMIDs: 24085763, 29191945); however, there has not been overwhelming evidence at this time to confirm that *THPO*-associated thrombocytopenia is indeed inherited in a semi-dominant manner. 

Summary of Experimental Data: 3.5 points: This gene-disease relationship is supported by in vitro functional assays. *THPO* is involved in megakaryopoiesis and thrombopoiesis, and loss of function variants in *THPO* lead to decrease in platelet counts (PMID: 23594368). Chen et al. showed that *THPO* physically interacts with MPL. (PMID: 20529857). A knock-out mouse model was generated by Sauvage et al, wherein homozygous KO mice recapitulated the thrombocytopenia phenotype while the heterozygous mice showed a significant reduction in platelet counts (PMID: 8627177)

In summary, the level of evidence to support the gene-disease relationship of *THPO* and autosomal recessive congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia is moderate. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged. 

This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hemostasis Thrombosis Working Group on March 24, 2022 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was heterozygous for the Arg31Ter nonsense variant in exon 3/6. NMD is predicted. The proband and her father are reported to be heterozygous. Thrombocytopenia was an incidental finding, and no bleeding tendency is reported in the family. Platelet size was normal or slightly larger. Authors suggest that this is a new entity of autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia. The proband is not scored as the autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia is not recognized as a distinct entity. It may be part of a continuum in severity (semi-dominant inheritance), but not all heterozygous individuals show the 'milder' features of thrombocytopenia. It is likely that this may not have been assessed in all heterozygous carriers. And, even though WES was performed, there may be other unknown factors leading to mild thrombocytopenia in the proband.

Note, proband is heterozygous, but entered as homozygous in order to add variant to the record in the GCI

evidence.rdfs:label: Noris_Family B_Patient II-1
evidence.previousTestingDescription: In vitro platelet aggregation and surface expression of GPIIb/IIIa and GPIb/IX were normal in the two individuals from Family B

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was heterozygous for the Arg31Ter nonsense variant in exon 3/6. NMD is predicted. The proband and her mother are reported to be heterozygous for this variant. Thrombocytopenia was an incidental finding, and no bleeding tendency is reported in the family. Platelet size was normal or slightly larger. Authors suggest that this is a new entity of autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia. The proband is not scored as the autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia is not recognized as a distinct entity. It may be part of a continuum in severity (semi-dominant inheritance), but not all heterozygous individuals show the 'milder' features of thrombocytopenia. It is likely that this may not have been assessed in all heterozygous carriers. And, even though WES was performed, there may be other unknown factors leading to mild thrombocytopenia in the proband.

Note, proband is marked as 'homozygous' in order to enter the variant for this heterozygous individual. In order to enter monoaallelic and biallelic variants, curation must be performed for semi-dominant inheritance.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cornish_Pedigree A_III-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Proband was enrolled into the NIHR BioResource for Rare Diseases or the ThromoGenomics studies.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mean serum TPO was 42 pg/ml (NV = 17-57). Mild mucocutaneous bleeding is reported with no additional phenotypic features.

evidence.dc:description:
The proband is reported to be heterozygous for the Glu204GlyfsTer123 frameshift variant that is predicted to result in a termination codon in exon 6/6. NMD is not predicted. Proband's mother and maternal grandfather are also reported to be carriers and show thrombocytopenia as well as increased MPV.

Authors suggest that this is a new entity of autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia. The proband is not scored as the autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia is not recognized as a distinct entity. It may be part of a continuum in severity (semi-dominant inheritance), with some heterozygous individuals showing the 'milder' features of thrombocytopenia. It is likely that this may not have been assessed in all heterozygous carriers. And, other contributing factors leading to mild thrombocytopenia in the proband have may not have been ruled out.
Functional studies in HEK293T cells reveal diminished secretion of TPO.

evidence.rdfs:label: Seo_Family B_II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of the entire THPO gene in family B was performed
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Platelet count = 18x10^9/L, MCV = 92.3 fL. Thrombocytopenia progressed to aplastic marrow. He died with multiorgan system failure 3 months after the first stem cell graft.

evidence.dc:description: The proband was homozygous for the missense variant, Arg99Trp (NM_000460.4). Functional evidence based on the variant transfected in HEK-293T cells showed MPL-dependent cell survival and proliferation, similar to wild-type. The authors suggest that since the homozygous patients showed absence of THPO in their serum, the Arg99Trp variant severely reduces THPO levels without affecting its function.

evidence.rdfs:label: Seo_Family A_III-I
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted gene capture panel sequencing of candidate genes was performed on family A
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Platelet count was 40x10^9/L. BM appeared hypocellular (5%-10% cellularity) with an absence of megakaryocytes. Proband was transfusion-dependent and underwent BMT. Four months after the second transplant, severe gastrointestinal and pulmonary hemorrhage led to his demise. THPO levels in proband's brother were undetectable.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Evaluation for known causes of inherited or acquired thrombocytopenia or BMF failed to reveal a diagnosis

evidence.dc:description: The proband was homozygous for the missense variant, Arg99Trp (NM_000460.4). Functional evidence based on the variant transfected in HEK-293T cells showed MPL-dependent cell survival and proliferation, similar to wild-type. The authors suggest that since the homozygous patients showed absence of THPO in their serum, the Arg99Trp variant severely reduces THPO levels without affecting its function.

evidence.rdfs:label: Seo_Family C_II-5
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Platelet count = 16x10^9/L. No severe bleeding complications. At the age of 10 months, a BM biopsy revealed a hypocellular marrow without clonal cytogenetic aberrations. Following romiplostim therapy, BM biopsy showed regeneration trilineage hematopoiesis with only mild morphologic signs of dysplasia.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Maternal alloimmune thrombocytopenia was ruled out.

evidence.dc:description: The proband was homozygous for the nonsense variant, Arg157Ter, in exon 6/6 of the THPO gene. NMD is not predicted; however authors note that the C-terminal glycan domain has been shown to be critical to protein function as its deletion has been previously shown to impair THPO production through its reduced secretion.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pecci_Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: THPO coding exons and intron-exon boundaries were sequenced
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Thrombocytopenia and neutropenia were severe. Platelet size was normal. Bone marrow was hypocellular with rare immature megakaryocytes
evidence.previousTestingDescription: BM showed normal karyotype. Fanconi anemia and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglinuria were excluded. MPL coding exons and intron-exon boundaries were sequenced

evidence.dc:description: The proband and his two siblings were found to have severe thrombocytopenia and other clinical features and carried the Arg119Cys missense variant.

n-vitro studies were performed: variants were transfected in HEK293T cells to produce THPO-conditioned media which was assessed to sustain growth of UT7-TPO cells. Studies showed that variant interfered with THPO secretion from the intracellular compartment, led to lower proliferation of the UT7-TPO cells, caused defective activation of all intracellular signaling kinases, although the stability of the protein was similar to WT.

evidence.rdfs:label: Dasouki_Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Bone marrow was hypocellular. Platelet count = 67 x 10^9/L
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Known genetic causes of aplastic anemia and bone marrow failure syndromes were excluded. Normal peripheral blood lymphocyte chromosome breakage and normal bone marrow karyotype (46,XX), serum Î± fetoprotein, and THPO levels.

evidence.dc:description: The proband was found to be homozygous for the missense change, Arg38Cys. Note, the variant is referred to as R17C in the paper, perhaps numbering in the mature protein. However, the abstract mentions c.112C>T which corresponds to R38C, and Pecci et al who cite this publication and performed functional studies refer to this variant as Arg38Cys.

Functional studies from PMID: 29191945 show that when variants were transfected in HEK293T cells to produce THPO-conditioned media which was assessed to sustain growth of UT7-TPO cells, variant interfered with THPO secretion from the intracellular compartment, led to lower proliferation of the UT7-TPO cells, and caused defective activation of all intracellular signaling kinases, although the stability of the protein was similar to WT.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cornish_Pedigree B_II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Proband was enrolled into the National Institute for Health Research BioResource for Rare Diseases  or referred for analysis with the ThromboGenomics high-throughput diagnostic platform
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mean serum TPO was 42 pg/ml (NV = 17-57). Mild mucocutaneous bleeding is reported with no additional phenotypic features.

evidence.dc:description:
The proband is reported to be heterozygous for the Leu269ProfsTer58 frameshift variant that is predicted to result in a termination codon in exon 6/6. NMD is not predicted. Proband's mother is also reported to be a carrier and shows thrombocytopenia as well as increased MPV.

Authors suggest that this is a new entity of autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia. The proband is not scored as the autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia is not recognized as a distinct entity. It may be part of a continuum in severity (semi-dominant inheritance), with some heterozygous individuals showing the 'milder' features of thrombocytopenia. It is likely that this may not have been assessed in all heterozygous carriers. And, other contributing factors leading to mild thrombocytopenia in the proband have may not have been ruled out.
Functional studies in HEK293T cells revealed diminished secretion of TPO.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cornish_Pedigree C_II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Proband was enrolled into the National Institute for Health Research BioResource for Rare Diseases or referred for analysis with the ThromboGenomics high-throughput diagnostic platform
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mean serum TPO was 42 pg/ml (NV = 17-57). Mild mucocutaneous bleeding is reported with no additional phenotypic features.

evidence.dc:description: Authors suggest that this is a new entity of autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia. The proband is not scored as the autosomal dominant thrombocytopenia is not recognized as a distinct entity. It may be part of a continuum in severity (semi-dominant inheritance), with some heterozygous individuals showing the 'milder' features of thrombocytopenia. It is likely that this may not have been assessed in all heterozygous carriers. And, other contributing factors leading to mild thrombocytopenia in the proband have may not have been ruled out.
Functional studies in HEK293T cells revealed that though overall concentration of TPO was similar to WT, the variant protein showed perinuclear localization, suggesting mistrafficking.

MPL is the receptor for TPO. Mutations in the gene MPL have been associated with thrombocythemia (Thrombocythemia 2) and the gene-disease relationship has been classified as moderate by the HT GCEP. Authors show that MPL physically interacts with TPO upon immunoprecipitation for TPO and western blotting with an anti-MPL antibody.
evidence.rdfs:label: Chen_Interaction with MPL

evidence.dc:description: THPO is directly involved in thrombopoiesis and loss of function variants in THPO lead to decrease in platelet counts.
evidence.rdfs:label: Deutsch_thrombopoiesis

evidence.dc:description: MPL is the receptor for thrombopoietin on the cell surface of HSCs, megakaryocytes and platelets, and along with THPO is involved in megakaryocytopoiesis and thrombopoiesis
evidence.rdfs:label: Deutsch_Function similar to MPL

evidence.dc:description: CBC performed on TPO-/- mice revealed 88% drop in platelet counts compared to WT mice. A significant increase in volume of the remaining platelets was also observed. The heterozygous TPO-/+ mice also showed a significant alteration in platelet counts (67% of WT). Other cell lineages were unaffected. Authors also determined that there is no redundancy in the TPO/MPL system and that TPO is the major physiological regulator of megakaryocytopoiesis. TPO knockout resulted in depletion of megakaryocytes and, as a result, platelets.
evidence.rdfs:label: Sauvage_TPO-/- mouse
